bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John R. Bullard, September 1, 1941

div1.p: Hench informs Bullard that he is forwarding his manuscript to Kean after Bullard's review. He asks Bullard for clarification concerning some of his remarks. Hench explains the difference between the Havana Yellow Fever Board and the U.S. Army Yellow Fever Board.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John R. Bullard, September 1, 1941

opener.dateline:
September 1, 1941 Mr. John R. Bullard
P. O. Box 59
St. Augustine, Florida

div1.p:
Thank you so much for sending me a corrected copy of my write-up of
your story. I thought Gen. Kean would be interested in it and sent him a copy.
He enjoyed reading it. He made a few comments your reaction to which I'd like
to know.

list.item:
1. His recollection was that your first attack of malaria was while
you were in Havana about 10 days after your departure from Dedham, Massachusetts
where your mother was then living. Kean stated that your malaria (the tropical
double tertian type) was brought to Dedham by Italian laborers working on a sewer.

2. To your recollection that Kean tried to dissuade you Kean remarked,
“This is not my memory of the case which is that I rather approved it.”

div1.p:
These are the only comments he made except to speak very pleasantly of
you and to say that your story seemed quite accurate.

Now let me comment on your corrections. I understand most of them. But
you say that “On the third day of your illness the Yellow Fever Board came out
from Habana to see us. It included Dr. Finlay.” I had quoted you as speaking of
the Havana Yellow Fever Board. This was a board of Cuban physicians familiar
with yellow fever. Reed had it set up so that his cases of experimental yellow
fever would be recognized as such by disinterested Cuban experts. Drs. Finlay
and Albertini were among those in this Havana Yellow Fever Board, a name used
to distinguish between that Yellow Fever Board and the U. S. Army Yellow Fever
Board. Should I therefore re-insert the term Havana Yellow Fever Board in your
story?

My “addenda” to your story (about which you said, “Why bring this in?”)
was added for my own information as a memorandum that you could not help me re-
garding some disputed points.

The colored reproductions of the painting of Walter Reed et al are being
finished. They are really fine. I'm sorry the late series of Carroll's cases
couldn't be included also. The painter said he “wouldn't paint a mob scene.” As
it is he was persuaded to increase the group from five to fifteen figures. I'll
see that you get a copy when they are out.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
